EEMB 2.title: Introductory Biology II--Ecology and Evolution
EEMB 2.prereq_description: MCDB 1A with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 2.comments: Concurrent enrollment in EEMB 7 not allowed. Reduced credit of 2.0 units will be given for those who have received credit for EEMB 7.
EEMB 2.description: Introduction to population and community ecology, and evolution.

EEMB 2L.title: Introductory Biology Laboratory II
EEMB 2L.prereq_description: MCDB 1A; concurrent enrollment in EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B.
EEMB 2L.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 4B or EEMB 4B or 5BL or MCDB 4B or 5BL. Same course as MCDB 1BL.
EEMB 2L.description: Laboratory investigations illustrate basic principles of animal and  plant physiology, ecology, and evolution.

EEMB 2Z.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 4BZ or EEMB 4BZ or 5BZ or MCDB 4BZ or 5BZ.
EEMB 2Z.description: Designed for transfer students who have completed part of EEMB 2 through transfer work. Topics will be selected by the department, as appropriate,  to fulfill the introductory biology requirement at UCSB.

EEMB 2LL.title: Introductory Biology Laboratory II
EEMB 2LL.description: Laboratory investigation s illustrate basis principles of ecology, evolution and biodiversity.

EEMB 3.title: Introductory Biology III
EEMB 3.prereq_description: MCDB 1A-B and EEMB 2 with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 3.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 4C or EEMB 4C or 5C.
EEMB 3.description: Introduction to the major groups of microbes, plants, and animals.

EEMB 3L.title: Introductory Biology Laboratory III
EEMB 3L.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B; and, concurrent enrollment in EEMB 3. Completion of MCDB 1BL or EEMB 2L with a grade of D- or better.
EEMB 3L.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 4C or EEMB 4C or5CL.
EEMB 3L.description: The diversity of microbes, plants, and animals is examined using living and preserved materials.

EEMB 3Z.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 4CZ or EEMB 4CZ or 5CZ.
EEMB 3Z.description: Designed for transfer students who have completed part of EEMB 3 through transfer work. Topics will be selected by the department, as appropriate,  to fulfill the introductory biology requirement at UCSB.

EEMB 4FS.title: Freshman Seminar
EEMB 4FS.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 4FS. Same   courseas MCDB 4FS.
EEMB 4FS.description: Selected topics of special interest designed to display the broad    diversityof the biological sciences. This course is strongly recommended for freshmen and/or prospective majors within the biological sciences.

EEMB 7.title: Principles of Evolution and Animal Physiology for Brain Sciences
EEMB 7.prereq_description: MCDB 6 or MCDB 1A all with a grade of C- or better
EEMB 7.comments: Not open to Prebio/EEMB/MCDB majors. Can't be used in lieu of EEMB 2 for prereqs. Unsuitable for health professions requiring 1 yr of intro bio. Can't take concurrently MCDB 1B/EEMB 2 or if completed.
EEMB 7.description: Introduction to the principles of evolution and animal physiology. Topics in evolution include the evidence for evolution, the process of microevolution, macroevolution, and basic phylogeny. Topics in animal physiology include tissues and organ systems, neural control, sensory perception, endocrine control, structural support and movement, circulation, immunity, respiration, digestion, reproduction, and development. This course is designed for psychological and brain sciences majors.

EEMB 21.title: General Botany
EEMB 21.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Botany 20 or Biology  4A-B-C; MCDB 5A-AL, EEMB 5B-BL or MCDB 5B-BL, and 5C-CL; MCDB 1B-1BL, EEMB 2-2L, EEMB 3-3L, 2 hours lab/ discussion.
EEMB 21.description: Unifying principles of biology, utilizing plants as exemplary material;  correlation of structure and function; genetics, selection, and evolution; energy transformation; growth of populations and the relation of plants to man; conservation.

EEMB 22.title: Concepts and Controversies in the Biological Sciences
EEMB 22.comments: Not open for credit toward graduation to students who completed EEMB 20, MCDB 20, EEMB W 22, MCDB 1A, EEMB 2, MCDB 1B, or EEMB 3. Concurrent enrollment in MCDB 20 or MCDB 1A not allowed.
EEMB 22.description: Introduction to the principles of evolution, physiology and ecology; emphasizing fundamental concepts and processes such as natural selection and speciation, photosynthesis and cellular respiration, animal and plant interactions, population dynamics, community structure, and biodiversity. Examines perspectives on currently relevant and biologically based topics such as evolution / scientific creationism, sociobiology, biotechnology, reproductive rights, pandemic disease, climate change, exobiology, and overpopulation.

EEMB W 22.title: Concepts and Controversies in the Biological Sciences
EEMB W 22.comments: Quarters usually offered: Summer. Not open for credit toward graduation to students who completed EEMB 20, MCDB 20, EEMB 22, MCDB 1A, EEMB 2, MCDB 1B, or EEMB 3. Concurrent enrollment in MCDB 20 or MCDB 1A not allowed.
EEMB W 22.description: Introduction to the principles of evolution, physiology and ecology; emphasizing fundamental concepts and processes such as natural selection and speciation, photosynthesis and cellular respiration, animal and plant interactions, population dynamics, community structure, and biodiversity. Examines perspectives on currently relevant and biologically based topics such as evolution / scientific creationism, sociobiology, biotechnology, reproductive rights, pandemic disease, climate change, exobiology, and overpopulation.

EEMB 40.title: Ecology of Infectious Disease
EEMB 40.description: Uses topical examples of emerging and resurgent diseases to illustrate key principles in ecology and epidemiology.  Examines how changing disease   ecology influences disease prevalence and how such changing patterns of  disease have influenced human history.

EEMB 50.title: Biology of Non-Infectious Disease
EEMB 50.description: An overview of both the biology and the history of the major     non-infectious diseases affecting humans.  Diseases covered will include cancer, heart disease, and diabetes.  An emphasis will be on changing  patterns of disease.

EEMB 55.title: Global Change Biology
EEMB 55.description: A general overview of the physical science of environmental change but with an emphasis on living organisms, the ecosystems in which they live, and the biological consequences of a changing planet.  The course will cover terrestrial and aquatic systems wtih special emphasis on ocean and critical marine ecosystems.

EEMB 84.title: Internship in Biological Sciences
EEMB 84.prereq_description: Lower-division standing; instructor and departmental approval required.
EEMB 84.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall. Students must have a 2.5 cumulative grade-point average. May be repeated for credit to a  maximum of 15 units, but no units may be applied toward the major.
EEMB 84.description: Opportunity to obtain practical biological-related research experience by working under faculty direction as an intern with local, state,   federal, or private agencies. A written report will be submitted for   evaluation.

EEMB 90.title: EEMB Colloquium
EEMB 90.description: Exposes students to current research in ecology, evolution, behavioral ecology, evolutionary ecology, physiological ecology, and marine biology, by eminent and nationally and internationally well-known biologists. Students attend the EEMB departmental seminar each week and participate in a discussion of the seminar research. Students complete a short weekly quiz regarding the content of each seminar presentation.

EEMB 90A.title: Getting into the Environment: Introduction to Ecological Science and Careers
EEMB 90A.comments: Open to biology majors only. Not major applicable.
EEMB 90A.description: Part of a NSF funded grant focused on improving STEM at Hispanic Serving Institutes (HSIs), called FUERTE, the course supports students as they transition into college, helps them choose their major and direction of study at UCSB, and forms a learning community. It also serves as an introduction to the FUERTE program, presents logistical information regarding program scheduling and requirements, and introduces students to ecological research, and research methods and tools.

EEMB 90B.title: Getting into the Environment: Introduction to Ecological Science and Careers II
EEMB 90B.comments: Open to biology majors only. Not major applicable.
EEMB 90B.description: Part of an NSF funded grant funded focused on improving STEM at Hispanic Serving Institutes (HSIs), called FUERTE, the course will continue to support students as they seek to pursue careers in environmental sciences. The course will focus on practical career skills development - ranging from CV building, to graduate school applications, to finding internships, and will continue to increase exposure to research methods and tools in ecology.

EEMB 92.title: Special Topics in Biology
EEMB 92.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units.
EEMB 92.description: Special topics in ecology, evolution and marine biology. Course content  varies. Information may be obtained in department office.

EEMB 94.title: Issues in Marine Conservation
EEMB 94.comments: Quarters usually offered: Summer. This seminar will be a component of a  Summer Institute in combination with two courses in Film Studies on    Environmental Media. Participation will be open only to students admitted  to the Institute.
EEMB 94.description: Seminar course exploring a variety of current conservation issues    affecting California's coastal ecosystems. Seminars include a range of   guest speakers working on the scientific issues underlying the marine  conservation challenges.

EEMB 96.title: Introduction to Curation of Natural History Collections
EEMB 96.comments:
Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Same course as ENV S 96.
Repeat Comments: EEMB 96 and ENV S 96 combined may be taken 3 times in total.
EEMB 96.description: Introduction to curation of natural history collections including vertebrate, plants, algae and lichen. Learn to collect, prepare, catalog, and preserve specimens via lectures, hands-on activities, and field trips. Collection focus changes quarterly. Internships available at conclusion of the course.
EEMB 96.recommended_prep: Completion of an introductory course in biology, ecology or environmental science.

EEMB 98.title: Readings in Biological Sciences
EEMB 98.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 grade-point average and are limited to 5  units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. Students are limited to 6 units of Biology 98 and EEMB     98combined. Maximum units 6 (3 per quarter). Biology 98 = EEMB + MCDB 98.
EEMB 98.description: Special readings on selected topics in biology. Individual conferences one one hour every week. Designed to broaden the out look and experience of  advanced lower-division students. Hours and credit by arrangement with any member of the staff.

EEMB 99.title: Introduction to Research
EEMB 99.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 grade-point average and are limited to 5  units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. Students are limited to 6 units of Biology 99 and EEMB     99combined. Maximum units 6 (3 per quarter). Biology 99 = EEMB + MCDB 99.
EEMB 99.description: Laboratory or field experience for advanced lower-division students. Hours and credit by arrangement with any member of the staff.

EEMB 101.title: Molecular Evolution
EEMB 101.prereq_description: EEMB 2 or MCDB 1A or Geology 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a
EEMB 101.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
EEMB 101.description: Major concepts in evolutionary biology, presented with a genetic emphasis. This course provides an introduction to the study of population genetic processes and the patterns of genomic evolution, adaptation, and speciation that result from these processes.

EEMB 102.title: Macroevolution: Biodiversity in Deep Time
EEMB 102.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 102.description: An introduction to the scientific methods used to study the tempo and mode of evolution above the species level and important topics in macroevolution such as the Cambrian explosion, the origin of novelties, the evolution of development, and phylogenetics.

EEMB 102H.title: Macroevolution-Honors
EEMB 102H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in EEMB 102; consent of instructor
EEMB 102H.description: Honors component of EEMB 102.  An in depth study of Macroevolution.

EEMB 103A.title: Flora and Vegetation of California
EEMB 103A.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites
EEMB 103A.description: An introduction to plant families, species, and communities in California by means of laboratory work and field observations, and including techniques of plant collection and identification. One three-day field trip is required in addition to the regularly scheduled laboratories.

EEMB 103B.title: Vegetation and Flora of California
EEMB 103B.prereq_description: EEMB 103A; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or
EEMB 103B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Botany 103B. 6 hours  lab/field combined.
EEMB 103B.description: A continuation of the material in EEMB 103A, with increased emphasis on  the composition and distribution of plant communities throughout   California. Two field trips, three to four days each, are required in  addition to the regularly scheduled laboratories.

EEMB 106.title: Biology of Fishes
EEMB 106.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 106.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 161.
EEMB 106.description: The evolution, systematics, biogeography, and ecology of fishes.

EEMB 107.title: Biology of Amphibians and Reptiles
EEMB 107.prereq_description: EEMB 113 and 113L both with a grade of C or better.
EEMB 107.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 130 or 130A.
EEMB 107.description: An introduction to the diversity, systematics, functional morphology and ecology of modern lineages of amphibians and reptiles.

EEMB 107L.title: Herpetology Lab
EEMB 107L.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 130 or 130L.
EEMB 107L.description: An intensive introduction to the diversity and systematics of amphibians and reptiles worldwide with an additional focus on the western North   American Herpetofauna.

EEMB 108.title: Vertebrate Evolutionary Morphology
EEMB 108.prereq_description: MCDB 1A; and, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B; and, EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 108.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 108.
EEMB 108.description: Lectures concern evolutionary and functional aspects of the development of structural complexity in vertebrates, emphasizing the role of size in  determining mechanical and physiological optima and limits, and the    constraints imposed by the evolutionary process. Labs involve dissections  and demonstrations.

EEMB 109.title: Vertebrate Paleontology
EEMB 109.prereq_description: EARTH 2 or 3 or 7 or 30, or MCDB 1A-AL or EEMB 2
EEMB 109.comments: Letter grade required for majors. Same course as Earth 148.
EEMB 109.description: Introduction to the history of vertebrate life, with emphasis on the   phylogenetic relationships of the major vertebrate groups.

EEMB 111.title: Parasitology
EEMB 111.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 111.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 111.
EEMB 111.description: An ecological approach to parasitism. Survey of parasites of humans and other animals. Discussion of evolutionary, genetic, immunological, sociological, political, and economic aspects. Laboratory stresses anatomy and life cycles of living material.

EEMB 111H.title: Parasitology-Honors
EEMB 111H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in EEMB 111; consent of instructor
EEMB 111H.description: Honors component of EEMB 111.  An in depth study of a topic in     parasitology.  A written report and an annotated bibliography are    required.

EEMB 112.title: Invertebrate Zoology
EEMB 112.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 112.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 112A.
EEMB 112.description: An introduction to the classification, structure, life histories, and habits of the major phyla of invertebrate animals (excluding annelids and arthropods), with emphasis on marine fauna of Santa Barbara area.

EEMB 113.title: Vertebrate Biology, Ecology and Evolution
EEMB 113.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 113.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 113A.
EEMB 113.description: Evolutionary and ecological principles as demonstrated by amphibians,  reptiles, birds, and mammals; competition and other species      interactions; diversity and systematics with special emphasis on   speciation theory.

EEMB 113L.title: Laboratory in Vertebrate Biology, Ecology, and Evolution
EEMB 113L.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 113AL.
EEMB 113L.description: Weekly field trips to numerous locations and laboratory work emphasizing classification, identification, and observation of local terrestrial   vertebrates. Introduction to techniques such as trapping and banding to  study vertebrates in the field.

EEMB 116.title: Invertebrate Zoology: Higher Invertebrates
EEMB 116.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 116.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 112B.
EEMB 116.description: An introduction to the classification, structure, life histories, and habits of annelids and arthropods, with emphasis on the aquatic fauna of the Santa Barbara area.

EEMB 117.title: Flow and Aquatic Ecosystems
EEMB 117.prereq_description: EEMB 142A-B-C; Mathematics 3A-B or 34A-B or Math 2A-B; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 117.description: Introduction to the interaction of hydrodynamics with aquatic organisms and ecosystems and use of quantitative approaches in aquatic ecology. Case studies include examples from lakes, rivers, kelp forests, and coral reefs.

EEMB 118.title: Entomology: insect biology, ecology, and evolution
EEMB 118.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2, and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 118.description: Provides an introduction to the science of entomology. Lectures, labs, and field experiences will cover topics in insect biology, diversity,  behavior, and ecology, and the importance of insects to humans and   agriculture.

EEMB 119.title: Ecology and Management of California Wildlands
EEMB 119.prereq_description: Environmental Studies 100 or EEMB 120 or EEMB 168.
EEMB 119.comments: Same course as Environmental Studies 119. One weekend fieldtrip is mandatory.
EEMB 119.description: Explore ecological processes in California habitats and the challenges of their management through field trips, discussions with land managers, lectures and readings. Focus on regional habitats including specialized habitats such as coastal salt marsh and vernal pools, and more widespread such as oak savanna and chaparral.

EEMB 120.title: Introduction to Ecology
EEMB 120.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 120.comments: Letter grade required for majors. Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 120.
EEMB 120.description: Major concepts in population and evolutionary ecology. Theoretical,    experimental, and field studies pertaining to population growth and    regulation, competition, predation, diversity, adaptation and life history strategies.

EEMB 120AL.title: Field and Laboratory Studies in Ecology
EEMB 120AL.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 120AL-BL.   Individual projects.
EEMB 120AL.description: Practical studies in ecology in both field and laboratory, emphasizing the design and analysis of experiments.

EEMB 120BL.title: Field and Laboratory Studies in Ecology
EEMB 120BL.prereq_description: EEMB 120AL; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or
EEMB 120BL.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 120AL-BL.   Individual projects.
EEMB 120BL.description: Practical studies in ecology in both field and laboratory. Individual  projects are emphasized.

EEMB 127.title: Plant Biology and Biodiversity
EEMB 127.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 127.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 127.
EEMB 127.description: Introduction to plant biology; the importance of plants to humans; taxonomic and ecological diversity; and evolutionary processes. Will serve as a foundation for all upper-division plant biology courses. Emphasis on life history variation; pollination; reproduction and mating strategies.

EEMB 127L.title: Plant Biology and Biodiversity Lab
EEMB 127L.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2, EEMB 3 and EEMB 127. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 127L.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 127L.
EEMB 127L.description: Computer, lab, greenhouse, and field experience in studies of plant anatomy, physiology, reproduction, pollination, morphology, and adaptation to different environments. Live material and herbarium collections used to demonstrate plant diversity, speciation, and genetic variation. Independent and team projects.

EEMB 128.title: Foundations of Ecosystem Restoration
EEMB 128.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2, and EEMB 3; or ENVS 1, 2, 3 and 60 or 100, and either Chem 1A, 1AL, 1B, or ENVS 15A, 15B, and 15BL. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 128.description: Integrates ecological principles with practical issues involved in ecosystem restoration. Beginning with the challenge of selecting goals and establishing a target trajectory, students evaluate how ecological knowledge can guide restoration and whether sustainable states or trajectories can be achieved.

EEMB 129.title: Introductory Genetics
EEMB 129.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3 with a grade of C or better.
EEMB 129.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed MCDB 101A-B. Concurrent enrollment in MCDB 101A or MCDB 101B not allowed. Reduced credit (2.0 units) to students who have credit for MCDB 101A.
EEMB 129.description: Introduction to genetics. Mendel's laws, structure, replication and expression of DNA, linkage and chromosomal aberrations, mutation and recombination, concepts of genetic variability, quantitative and populationgenetics.

EEMB 130.title: Population Genetics
EEMB 130.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3 all with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 130.comments: EEMB 129 recommended. Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 130C.

EEMB 130C.title: Aquatic Food and Resource Management
EEMB 130C.prereq_description: Environmental Studies 100 or MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 130C.description: Introduction to the use and protection of aquatic food resources globally. Familiarization with the primary literature and key ecological concepts to identify the impacts which influence fisheries and aquaculture and in turn how these different food systems impact wild aquatic species and ecosystems. Offers an applied, food system perspective connecting ecological theory with policy and management.

EEMB 131.title: Principles of Evolution
EEMB 131.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3 or EARTH 2 and 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 131.comments: Same course as EARTH 121. Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 131.
EEMB 131.description: A foundation course concerning the mechanisms of evolution at micro- and macroevolutionary levels, and interpretation of the resulting patterns of adaptation and organic diversity.

EEMB 132.title: The Early Evolution of Life and its Environmental Context
EEMB 132.prereq_description: MCDB 1A & MCDB 1B & EEMB 2 & EEMB 3 (all with a minimum grade of C- or
EEMB 132.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 243. Quarters usually offered: Spring,   Fall.
EEMB 132.description: The first 3.5 billion years of life and the environmental context in   which it evolved. Highly multidisciplinary, drawing on evidence from   geology, geochemistry, paleontology, and comparative biology.

EEMB 133.title: Biodiversity and Conservation Biology
EEMB 133.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 133.description: An integration of concepts central to effectively describing biodiversity patterns on our planet and better understanding the dynamics by which wildlife and ecosystems are altered by people. Includes exposure to topics such a extinction dynamics, climate change, and the human dimensions of biodiversity change. Course reviews classical and next-generation tools for conserving nature.

EEMB 134.title: Biology of Seaweeds and Phytoplankton
EEMB 134.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 134.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 134.
EEMB 134.description: Overview on the biology of macroalgae and phytoplankton, with emphasis on  living and adapting in the various environments. Topics include    form-function, ecophysiology, unique aspects of biochemistry,      antiherbivorestrategies, applied phycology and mariculture.

EEMB 135.title: Invertebrate Paleobiology
EEMB 135.prereq_description: MCDB 1A & MCDB 1B & EEMB 2 & EEMB 3 (all with a grade of C- or better) or  Earth 3 or 30 or 111.
EEMB 135.description: Important topics in paleobiology are discussed in the context of the   evolutionary history of invertebrate animal life. These include    macroevolutionary theory, diversification and extinction events,   ecological and geobiological interactions through time, and the    incompleteness of the fossil record.

EEMB 136.title: Principles of Paleontology
EEMB 136.comments: Same course as EARTH 111. Letter grade required for majors. Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 111.
EEMB 136.description: The ecological structure and evolution of the biosphere as illustrated by the fossil record.

EEMB 136L.title: Principles of Paleontology Laboratory
EEMB 136L.comments: Same course as EARTH 111L. Letter grade required for majors. Not open  for credit to students who have have completed Biology 111L.
EEMB 136L.description: Exercises and projects in the identification and interpretation of   fossil taxa and fossil communities.

EEMB 137.title: Plant Paleobiology
EEMB 137.comments: Same course as EARTH 141. Letter grade required for majors. Not open for credit to students who have completed Botany 110, or Geol 141.
EEMB 137.description: Examination of the history of land plants; the systematics, morphology,  and phylogeny of major groups. Major evolution and biogeographic   patterns.

EEMB 137L.title: Plant Paleobiology Laboratory
EEMB 137L.prereq_description: EEMB 137 or EARTH 141 (may be taken concurrently).
EEMB 137L.comments: Same course as EARTH 141L. Letter grade required for majors. Not open  for credit to students who have completed Botany 110L or Geol 111L.
EEMB 137L.description: Anatomy, morphology, and systematics of fossil plants from the specimens.

EEMB 138.title: Ethology and Behavioral Ecology
EEMB 138.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 138.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 138.
EEMB 138.description: Animal behavior and social organization viewed from evolutionary and whole animal perspectives. Specific topics stress environmental influences and natural selection and include: classical ethology, development and learning, communication, foraging, aggression, territoriality, mating systems, parental care, altruism, and sociobiology.

EEMB 140.title: General Plant Ecology
EEMB 140.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; completion of all listed
EEMB 140.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Botany 140.
EEMB 140.description: An introduction to the principles of plant ecology.

EEMB 140L.title: General Plant Ecology Lab
EEMB 140L.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; and, EEMB 140 (may be taken
EEMB 140L.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Botany 140L.

EEMB 142A.title: Aquatic Communities
EEMB 142A.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 142A.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed EEMB 145C.
EEMB 142A.description: A survey of the patterns of distribution, diversity, an abundance of species in marine and freshwater communities, with an emphasis on the dynamic interactions which shape these patterns.

EEMB 142B.title: Environmental Processes in Oceans and Lakes
EEMB 142B.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 142B.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 145A.
EEMB 142B.description: A discussion of biological, chemical, physical, and optical processes in marine and freshwater environments and the linkage between these     processes. Emphasis on primary production, global biogeochemical cycles, nutrient dynamics, and synoptic mapping of biological and physical   patterns.

EEMB 142C.title: Environmental Processes in Oceans and Lakes
EEMB 142C.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 142C.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 145B.
EEMB 142C.description: A continuation of EEMB 142B with emphasis on secondary productivity, ecology of higher trophic levels including zoo plankton and fish, food web dynamics, benthic-pelagic coupling, ocean circulation, and biogeographical aspects of pelagic communities.

EEMB 142AL.title: Methods in Aquatic Community Ecology
EEMB 142AL.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 145CL.
EEMB 142AL.description: Experience in the field techniques of aquatic community ecology.

EEMB 142BL.title: Chemical and Physical Methods of Aquatic Environments
EEMB 142BL.prereq_description: EEMB 142B (may be taken concurrently); Completion of all listed
EEMB 142BL.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 145AL. To   complete the laboratory and field protion of EEMB 145AL requires at    least 8 hrs/wk. of in-class time (i.e., 0900 to 1700). Two field trips   require 10 hours. Oral presentations are also required.
EEMB 142BL.description: A survey of physical and chemical methods used by limnologists and   oceanographers supplemented with field observations.

EEMB 142CL.title: Methods of Aquatic Biology
EEMB 142CL.prereq_description: EEMB 142C (may be taken concurrently); Completion of all listed
EEMB 142CL.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed EEMB 145BL.
EEMB 142CL.description: Laboratory and field techniques used to measure various biological   processes including productivity, and to sample, identify, enumerate, and  culture marine organisms.

EEMB 143.title: Ecological Physiology
EEMB 143.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 143.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 143.
EEMB 143.description: Consideration of the physiological responses and adaptations of animals to their environments. Emphasis on the underlying physiological and     biochemical mechanisms. A comparative approach in nature emphasizing   aquatic animals.

EEMB 143L.title: Laboratory in Ecological Physiology
EEMB 143L.prereq_description: EEMB 143(may be taken concurrently); Completion of all listed
EEMB 143L.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 143L.
EEMB 143L.description: Semi-independent study lab to accompany EEMB 143. Study of the     physiological responses and adaptations of animals to their environment. Aquatic animals emphasized.

EEMB 144.title: Marine Microbiology
EEMB 144.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 144.description: Exploration of evolution, ecology, biochemistry, and genetics of marine  bacteria. Topics include: historical perspective, molecular approaches in  microbial ecology, trophic interactions/biogeochemistry, physiological   adaptations, and biochemistry and genetics of selected systems     bioluminescence, deep-sea adaptations, cell-surface interactions,    starvation survival).

EEMB 144L.title: Marine Microbiology Lab
EEMB 144L.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; concurrent enrollment in EEMB 144 or 142B; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or
EEMB 144L.description: A laboratory survey of the diversity, physiology and ecology of marine   prokaryotes, and methods used to identify, quantify and measure their  activities.

EEMB 145.title: Terrestrial Microbiology
EEMB 145.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2, and EEMB 3 all with a grade of C- or better
EEMB 145.description: Exploration of the diversity of archaea, bacteria, and fungi     associated with humans, animals, plants, and extreme terrestrial   environments. Topics include ecology, evolution, genetics,     systematics, and physiology with special focus on species interactions among microbes or between hosts and microbes.

EEMB 146.title: Biometry
EEMB 146.prereq_description: Mathematics 2A-B or 3A-B or 34A-B; and PSTAT 5A or PSTAT 5LS or PSTAT 109 or Math 4A or Psy 5;
EEMB 146.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 146A or EEMB 146A.
EEMB 146.description: Linear models and least squares fitting: simple and multiple linear regression; analysis of variance (fixed, random and mixed models; crossed and nested effects; balanced and unbalanced designs); analysis of covariance, factorial designs; incomplete layouts; use of transformations.

EEMB W 146.title: Biometry
EEMB W 146.prereq_description: Mathematics 2A-B or 3A-B or 34A-B; and PSTAT 5A or PSTAT 5LS or PSTAT 109 or Math 4A or Psy 5;
EEMB W 146.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 146A or EEMB 146A. Same course as EEMB 146.
EEMB W 146.description: Linear models and least squares fitting: simple and multiple linear regression; analysis of variance (fixed, random and mixed models; crossed and nested effects; balanced and unbalanced designs); analysis of covariance, factorial designs; incomplete layouts; use of transformations.

EEMB 147.title: Coral Reef Biology and Ecology
EEMB 147.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed
EEMB 147.description: Coral reefs are highly diverse ecosystems that provide important ecosystem services across many areas of the tropics. Introduction to the taxonomy, biology, and ecology of the main groups of coral reef inhabitants.   Analysis and discussion of the biology and ecological relationships of reef algae, plants and animals as well as contemporary challenges to the health and resilience of reefs, and potential conservation strategies to mitigate stressors on reefs.

EEMB 148.title: Ecology of Running Waters
EEMB 148.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 148.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 148.
EEMB 148.description: Introduction to the structure and function of river ecosystems, including physical and chemical characteristics, nutrient cycling and transport, biodiversity, biological interactions, conservation, and restoration. Discussion of bioassessment as a tool for measuring biological integrity (water quality and habitat health).

EEMB 148L.title: Investigations in Stream Ecology
EEMB 148L.prereq_description: EEMB 148 (may be taken concurrently); Completion of all listed
EEMB 148L.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 148L.
EEMB 148L.description: Introduction to field methods used in lotic ecology. Design and execution  of research projects emphasized.

EEMB 150A.title: Microbial Diversity I
EEMB 150A.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2, MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 150A.description: An investigation of the metabolic diversity of bacteria and archaea with an emphasis on microbial evolution, energetics, and the ecological implications of diversity. Required laboratory is an inquiry-based introduction to classical methods of enrichment and isolation of diverse microbes from the environment and molecular identification of isolates. Basic introduction to bioinformatic analysis of microbial phylogeny using sequence data generated in the course.

EEMB 152.title: Applied Marine Ecology
EEMB 152.prereq_description: Environmental Studies 100, or MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3; and Mathematics 3A or 34A. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 152.description: Introduction to the application of ecological principles and methods to environmental problems in marine habitats. Focus on problems that are local, regional, and global in scale. Concepts illustrated with case studies.

EEMB 153.title: Ecology of Lakes and Wetlands
EEMB 153.prereq_description: EEMB 142B; and, EEMB 142A or EEMB 120; Completion of all listed
EEMB 153.description: An examination of ecological aspects of lakes, wetlands, and their   catchments integrating biogeochemical processes, biological-physical   coupling, and population and community ecology. Applications of remote sensing and ecological models; human-caused impacts and their management.

EEMB 154.title: Integrative Physiology
EEMB 154.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; and, Chemistry 109A-B; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 154.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 153A.
EEMB 154.description: A rigorous introduction to how animals function, integrating information and concepts appropriate to the understanding of physiological processes from the level of molecules to whole organisms.

EEMB 155CC.title: Global Change Biology
EEMB 155CC.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 155CC.description: Explores the impact of environmental change (e.g., global warming, ocean acidification, drought) on ecosystems and organisms. Case studies and readings from the primary literature are used. The course covers both terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.

EEMB 156.title: Biology of Reproduction
EEMB 156.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 156.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 156.
EEMB 156.description: Examination of hormonal mechanisms regulating initiation/maintenance of reproductive function in vertebrates. Review of regulation of fertilization/pregnancy/parturition. Endocrine aspects do not duplicate topics covered in EEMB 155, and provide background in physiology for MCDB 126B.

EEMB 157.title: Cell Physiology
EEMB 157.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 157.description: An analysis of processes fundamental to the functioning of cells, using  actual examples from the protista. These processes include, but are not  limited to, membrane structure and function, motility, metabolite    transport, protein trafficking, energy acquisition and utilization.

EEMB 157A.title: Cell Physiology
EEMB 157A.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 157A.description: An analysis of processes fundamental to the functioning of cells, using actual examples from the protista. These processes include, but are not limited to, membrane structure and function, motility, metabolite transport, protein trafficking, energy acquisition and utilization.

EEMB 157B.title: Animal Physiology
EEMB 157B.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 157B.description: Fundamentals of animal physiology. Covers the major systems including nervous, circulatory, respiratory, osmoregulatory, digestion, locomotion, and reproduction with an emphasis on animal diversity.

EEMB 157C.title: Plant Physiology
EEMB 157C.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 157C.description: A study of the link between structure and function that contributes to the development, reproduction, and diversity of plants. There will be a  special emphasis on primary literature reading and analyses.

EEMB 158.title: Climate Change Impacts on Marine Ecosystems
EEMB 158.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 158.description: Explores the impacts of climate change and other types of anthropogenic perturbation on organisms and processes in marine ecosystems. Emphasis is placed on ocean acidification, warming and deoxygenation, as well as plastic and oil pollution. Topics discussed include threats to marine diversity and ecosystem function, latitudinal shifts in productivity and diversity, changes in the global cycling of elements such as carbon, and the cost of climate change on food security.

EEMB W 158.title: Climate Change Impacts on Marine Ecosystems
EEMB W 158.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB W 158.description: Explores the impacts of climate change and other types of anthropogenic perturbation on organisms and processes in marine ecosystems. Emphasis is placed on ocean acidification, warming and deoxygenation, as well as plastic and oil pollution. Topics discussed include threats to marine diversity and ecosystem function, latitudinal shifts in productivity and diversity, changes in the global cycling of elements such as carbon, and the cost of climate change on food security.

EEMB 159.title: Tropical Ecology
EEMB 159.prereq_description: MCDB 1A and MCDB 1B and EEMB 2 and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 159.description: Introduction to the structure and function of tropical ecosystems, including physical and chemical characteristics, nutrient cycling and transport, biodiversity, biological interactions, conservation, and restoration. Discussion of case studies and the use ecological models as tools for exploring the dynamics of habitat fragmentation, coral reef degradation, and the spread of infectious disease as it relates to climate change.

EEMB 163.title: Deep-Sea Biology
EEMB 163.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 163.comments:
Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 153.
Repeat Comments: Pamela G Bayer: when the electronic MCA for EEMB 163 was created it was mistakenly stated that it had been offered under two former numbers: Biol 153 and EEMB 153. EEMB 153 is a completely different course, having no overlap with EEMB 163 and the mistake has been corrected (above).
EEMB 163.description: Consideration of the biology of midwater and benthic organisms living  beneath the euphotic zone. Emphasis on dynamic aspects of biological   processes in this unique environment. Surveys of major deep-sea taxa and the history of deep-sea biology are included.

EEMB 165.title: Fields Studies in Marine Ecological Physiology
EEMB 165.prereq_description: MCDB 1A-1B, EEMB 2 and 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a
EEMB 165.description: An integration of fields and laboratory approaches to questions in   marine ecological physiology. Using local coastal field sites,     participants conduct a team research project. Participants collect,  analyze, and present the results. Involves occasional field trips and  lab work.

EEMB 166.title: Field Approaches to Terrestial Plant and Ecosystem Ecology
EEMB 166.prereq_description: EEMB 2 and 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 166.description: An intensive lecture and field course in local habitats examining    biological invasions, resource cycling, vegetation succession, fire    ecology, and seed banks. Lectures introduce ecological principles, and   field labs demonstrate methodology. An additional weekend lab or outside project is required.

EEMB 167.title: Applied Freshwater Ecology
EEMB 167.prereq_description: EEMB 2 and 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 167.description: Providing sufficient quantities of high quality freshwater will be the   single biggest challenge facing humanity in the next century.  The course  explores the scientific basis for evaluating and addressing the impacts of environmental change of freshwater ecosystems.

EEMB 168.title: Conservation Ecology
EEMB 168.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 168.description: Introduction to the practical application of biological principles to conserving biodiversity. Covers tools and theory derived from both ecology and evolutionary biology such as metapopulation theory and population viability analysis as applied to real world examples.

EEMB 169.title: The Effects of Climate Change on Marine Ecosystems
EEMB 169.prereq_description: MCDB 1A,MCDB 1B,EEMB 2,and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites  with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 169.description: Covers the causes and effects of climate change on coastal and open  ocean environments. Examples will include the effects of deoxygenation,  ocean acidification, warming and pollution both in the modern ocean and  using the paleorecord.

EEMB 170.title: Biology of the Marine-Land Interface
EEMB 170.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 170.comments: Letter grade required for majors. Not open for credit to students who  have completed Biology 141. Offered during summer session only.
EEMB 170.description: Influence of physical factors on adaptations of shoreline organisms with emphasis on the arthropods.

EEMB 171.title: Ecosystem Processes
EEMB 171.prereq_description: Environmental Studies 100 or MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3. Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 171.comments: Same course as Environmental Studies 171. Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 171.
EEMB 171.description: An examination of the key processes that regulate ecosystem productivity and function in terrestrial ecosystems. Specific foci include: plant- soil linkages including decomposition and nutrient supply, and the role of above- and below-ground community composition on element cycles.

EEMB 172.title: Theoretical Population Ecology
EEMB 172.prereq_description: MCDB 1A-B; and EEMB 2-3; and Math 3A-B or 34A-B or 2A-B; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a C- or better.
EEMB 172.description: Examines the ecological theory pertaining to population dynamics, species interactions, and community properties, and explore how mathematical and computer modeling has influenced the development of ecological theory.  Includes case studies and computer exercises.

EEMB 174.title: Advanced Biostatistics using Bayesian Methods
EEMB 174.prereq_description: EEMB 146 with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 174.description: A model-based approach to modern methods in data analysis. Comparison of statistical approaches including frequentist, likelihood, and Bayesian techniques. Methods for simulating data, estimating parameters for single variable models, constructing multivariate and hierarchical models, model comparison using information criteria, and model suitability using posterior predictive analysis.

EEMB 179.title: Ecological Modeling
EEMB 179.prereq_description: Mathematics 34A-B or 3A-B or 2A-B; completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EEMB 179.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 179.
EEMB 179.description: An introduction to mathematical and computer models in studies of the natural environment with emphasis on population dynamics and species interactions. Case studies of interacting physical, chemical and biological phenomena.

EEMB 179H.title: Ecological Modeling - Honors
EEMB 179H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in EEMB 179 and consent of instructor.
EEMB 179H.description: Honors component of EEMB 179 designed to permit an in-depth study    involvingformulation, analysis and interpretation of an ecological model.  A written report on the work is required.

EEMB 180.title: Evolutionary theory and models of behavioral processes
EEMB 180.prereq_description: MCDB 1A-B; EEMB 2-3; Math 3A-B or Math 34A-B or Math 2A-B; C- or better in all listed prerequisites.
EEMB 180.description: A mathematical approach to understanding the process of evolutionary change with an emphasis on behavioral strategies starting wtih natural selection, frequency dependent selection, sex ratio, and selection for local adaptation.  Using an evolutionary framework, the consequences of behavioral strategies will be studied, including foraging strategies, mating behavior, and social behavior.

EEMB 182.title: Communicating Ocean Science
EEMB 182.prereq_description: Sophmore standing or higher; consent of instructor.
EEMB 182.comments: At least one quarter of biology, chemistry, geology, or physics and an   interest in marine science.
EEMB 182.description: Students interested in improving their ability to communicate their    scientific knowledge by teaching in K-12, college, and public education  settings. Course combines instruction in inquiry-based teaching methods  and learning pedagogy with 10 weeks of supervised field experience.    Students practice communicating scientific knowledge and receive mentoring on how to improve their presentations.

EEMB 183.title: Introduction to Teaching in Biology
EEMB 183.prereq_description: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.
EEMB 183.comments: May be repeated for credit in combination with MCDB 183 to a maximum of 5 units but no units may be applied toward the major.
EEMB 183.description: Students will assist instructor in teaching course in which the student previously received a grade of A or better. Activities will be determined in consultation with the instructor and may include leading discussion, laboratory, or tutorial section(s), attending lectures, and grading exams.

EEMB 184.title: Internship in Biological Sciences
EEMB 184.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall. Students must have a 2.5 cumulative grade-point average. May be repeated for credit to a  maximum of 15 units.
EEMB 184.description: Opportunity to obtain practical biological related experience by working under faculty direction as an intern with local, state, federal, or    private agencies. A written report will be submitted for evaluation.

EEMB 185.title: Field Work in Oceanography
EEMB 185.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units but only 4 units may be applied toward the major. Hours: variable, 3-24 hours minimum.
EEMB 185.description: Participation as a member of a scientific party on Scripps Institution   (UCSD), NMFS, and UCSB oceanographic cruises. Cruise duration is variable  (7 to 60 days), and course units will vary with cruise duration.     Supervision by scientific party leader. Report required.

EEMB 188RE.title: Conservation and Restoration Seminar
EEMB 188RE.comments: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units; may be repeated for credit in  major to a maximum of 4 units.
EEMB 188RE.description: Seminar explores current topics in conservation biology and restoration  ecology including basic and applied questions related to the conservation, restoration and management of populations,communities and ecosystems.  Presentations and discussions may include model ecosystem studies, hands on restoration or conservation projects & lessons learned, and political,  economic and philosophical issues.

EEMB 190.title: EEMB Colloquium
EEMB 190.comments: Up to 2.0 units may apply to the major.
EEMB 190.description: Exposes students to current research topics in ecology and evolutionary  biology. Students will attend the EEMB departmental seminar each week  and  participate in a discussion of the seminar research, critiquing the presentation and the content, and drawing parallels with topics from   other courses. Students will write a term paper describing and     critiquing one seminar.

EEMB 192.title: Special Topics in Biological Sciences
EEMB 192.prereq_description: Upper-division standing in EEMB or MCDB and consent of instructor.
EEMB 192.comments: May be repeated for credit in combination with Biology 192 and MCDB 192. Maximum units for credit in major: 8 for BS; 4 for BA.
EEMB 192.description: Special topics of current importance in biological sciences. Course    contentwill vary. Information may be obtained from the department office.

EEMB 194P.title: Population Ecology
EEMB 194P.prereq_description: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.
EEMB 194P.comments: May be repeated for credit in combination with Biology 194AA-ZZ and MCDB 194AA-ZZ to a maximum of 8 units. Individual letter designations may be  repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units. Maximum units for credit in major: 8 BS; 4 BA. See also credit limits with other courses in    description of major requirements.

EEMB 194AAZZ.title: Group Studies for Advanced Students
EEMB 194AAZZ.prereq_description: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.
EEMB 194AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit in combination with Biology 194AA-ZZ and MCDB 194AA-ZZ to a maximum of 8 units. Individual letter designations may be  repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units. Maximum units for credit in major: 8 BS; 4 BA. See also credit limits with other courses in    descriptionof major requirements.

EEMB 197.title: Directed Studies
EEMB 197.prereq_description: EEMB major; consent of department; upper-division standing; completion of  two upper-division courses in MCDB or EEMB; and a 2.5 GPA in
EEMB 197.comments: Misc: Students must have a minimum grade-point average of 2.5 in     upper-division major courses and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 197/198/199/199RA courses combined. Maximum units for credit defined on major sheets. See also credit limits with other courses  in description of major requirements.
EEMB 197.description: Hours and credit by arrangement with any faculty member.

EEMB 198.title: Directed Readings
EEMB 198.prereq_description: EEMB major; consent of department; upper-division standing; completion of  two upper-division courses in MCDB or EEMB.
EEMB 198.comments: Students must have a minimum grade-point average of 3.0 in upper-division  major courses. Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units  total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. Maximum units for  credit in major: 8 BS; 4 BA. See also creditt limits with other courses in description of major requirements.
EEMB 198.description: Individual conferences one hour every two weeks. Special readings designed to broaden the outlook of students and to knit into a cohesive whole the basic principles underlying the major disciplines in the field.

EEMB 199.title: Independent Studies
EEMB 199.prereq_description: EEMB majors only; consent of instructor and department; upper-division
EEMB 199.comments: Students must have a minimum grade-point average of 3.0 in upper-division  major courses and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. Maximum units for credit in major: 8 BS; 4 BA. See also credit limits with other courses in    description of major requirements. Tutorial, 1-3 hours; field, 1-5 hours.
EEMB 199.description: Hours and credit by arrangement with any faculty member. Laboratory or   field.

EEMB 201.title: Molecular Evolution
EEMB 201.prereq_description: EEMB 2 or MCDB 1A or Geol 3 or instructor approval
EEMB 201.description: Major concepts in evolutionary biology, presented with a genetic emphasis. Provides an introduction to the study of population genetic processes and  the patterns of genomic evolution, adaptation, and speciation that result  from these processes.

EEMB 211.title: Parasitology
EEMB 211.prereq_description: EEMB 2-2L or MCDB 1B-BL; and, EEMB 3-3L or equivalents.
EEMB 211.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 211.
EEMB 211.description: An ecological approach to parasitism. Survey of parasites of humans and  other animals. Discussion of evolutionary, genetic, immunological,   sociological, political, and economic aspects. Laboratory stresses anatomy and life cycles of living material.

EEMB 212.title: Topics in Parasitology
EEMB 212.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Zoology 212.
EEMB 212.description: Consideration of theoretical aspects of parasite ecology, evolution, and physiology. General biology of a selected group of parasites chosen in consultation with students. Laboratory: individualized study of    parasitological aspects relevant to students' general interests. An oral and written report is required.

EEMB 217.title: Flow and Aquatic Ecosystems
EEMB 217.prereq_description: EEMB 142A-B-C or equivalent; and, Math 3A-B or 34A-B or equivalent.
EEMB 217.description: An introduction to the interaction of hydrodynamics with aquatic organisms and ecosystems and use of quantitative approaches in aquatic ecology. Case studies include examples from lakes, rivers, kelp forests, and coral reefs.

EEMB 218.title: Entomology: Insect Biology, Ecology, and Evolution
EEMB 218.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2, and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed
EEMB 218.comments: Concurrently offered with EEMB 118. Quarters usually offered: Summer. May be taught concurrently with EEMB 118.
EEMB 218.description: Provides an introduction to the science of entomology. Lectures, labs, and field experiences will cover topics in insect biology, diversity, behavior, and ecology, and the importance of insects to humans and agriculture. An enhanced insect collection including a greater number of specimens overall and specimens from more difficult/rare families properly curated and identified. A systematic literature review or original concept paper on an entomological topic relevant to the students research area or interests.

EEMB 222.title: Experimental Design Workshop
EEMB 222.description: A workshop for students focusing on statistica issues in the design and  analysis of ecological experiments. Includes extensive analyses of real  data sets supplied by the students. Specific topics vary each year.

EEMB 228.title: Ecological Constraints to Ecosystem Restoration
EEMB 228.description: Integrates ecological principles with practical issues involved in   ecosystem restoration. Beginning with the challenge of selecting goals and establishing a target trajectory, students evaluate how ecological   knowledge can guide restoration and whether sustainable states or    trajectories can be achieved.

EEMB 241.title: Advanced Physiological Plant Ecology
EEMB 241.prereq_description: MCDB 1A-AL; and, MCDB 1B-BL or EEMB 2-2L; and, EEMB 3-3L; and, EEMB 140 or one course in plant physiology.
EEMB 241.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Botany 241.
EEMB 241.description: A study of the evnironmental and physiological parameters of plant   distributions and niches with special reference to methods.

EEMB 242.title: Marine Ecology and Conservation
EEMB 242.description: Provides an in-depth understanding of the biotic and abiotic interactions that determine ecological processes in marine environments, how these processes shape the structure of marine ecosystems, and how these principles are used to direct marine conservation and management.

EEMB 243.title: Biological Oceanography
EEMB 243.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 243.
EEMB 243.description: Current concepts in biological oceanography focusin on the coupling of biotic processes to ocean physics, chemistry and sedimentation. Emphasis on areas of active research with critical evaluation of current and seminalliterature.

EEMB 244.title: Marine Microbiology
EEMB 244.prereq_description: MCDB 1A-AL; and, MCDB 1B-BL or EEMB 2-2L; and, EEMB 3-3L; and, MCDB 110,
EEMB 244.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 252.
EEMB 244.description: Exploration of evolution, ecology, biochemistry, and genetics of marine  bacteria. Topics include: historical perspective, molecular approaches in  in microbial ecology, trophic interactions/biogeochemistry, physiological  adaptations, and biochemistry and genetics of selected systems     (bioluminescence, deep-sea adaptations, cell-surface interactions,   starvation survival).

EEMB 247.title: Quantitative Methods in Biology
EEMB 247.description: A review of quantitative methods required to develop models of biological  and ecological systems. Topics illustrated through computer exercises.

EEMB 248.title: Ecology of Running Waters
EEMB 248.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 248.
EEMB 248.description: Review of literature on the physics, chemistry, and biology of running   water ecosystems.

EEMB 250A.title: Microbial Diversity I
EEMB 250A.description: An investigation of the metabolic diversity of bacteria and archaea with an emphasis on microbial evolution, energetics, and the ecological implications of diversity. Required laboratory is an inquiry-based introduction to classical methods of enrichment and isolation of diverse microbes from the environment and molecular identification of isolates. Basic introduction to bioinformatic analysis of microbial phylogeny using sequence data generated in the course.

EEMB 253.title: Ecology of Lakes and Wetlands
EEMB 253.prereq_description: EEMB 142B; and, EEMB 142A or EEMB 120 or equivalent.
EEMB 253.description: An examination of ecological aspects of lakes, wetlands and their physical coupling and population and community ecology. Applications of remote  sensing and ecological models; human-caused impacts and their management.

EEMB 264.title: Marine Pharmacology
EEMB 264.description: History and scope of the use of natural product probes in biology and  theirrelationship to physiology, chemistry, and biochemistry.

EEMB 271.title: Ecosystem Processes
EEMB 271.prereq_description: Environmental Studies 13 or MCDB 1B-BL or EEMB 2-2L.
EEMB 271.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 271.
EEMB 271.description: An examination of carbonand nutrient cycling in terrestrial ecosystems.  Specific foci will include plant-soil linkages including decomposition and nutrient supply, and the role of above- and below-ground community   composition on element cycles.

EEMB 274.title: Advanced Biostatistics using Bayesian Methods
EEMB 274.description: A model-based approach to modern methods in data analysis. Comparison of statistical approaches including frequentist, likelihood, and Bayesian techniques. Methods for simulating data, estimating parameters for single variable models, constructing multivariate and hierarchical models, model comparison using information criteria, and model suitability using posterior predictive analysis.

EEMB 275.title: Environmental Adaptation
EEMB 275.description: Introduction to the concepts and literature concerning mechanisms    underlying physiological and evolutionary adaptations that allow animals to exploit various environments and adapt to environmental change. Open  to graduate students from various disciplines. Lectures and student  presentations.

EEMB 279.title: Ecological Modeling
EEMB 279.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 279.
EEMB 279.description: An introduction to mathematical and computer models in studies of the natural environment with emphasis on population dynamics and species interactions. Case studies of interacting physical, chemical and biological phenomena.

EEMB 280.title: Evolutionary theory and models of behavioral processes

EEMB 285.title: Field Work in Oceanography
EEMB 285.prereq_description: Upper-division courses in aquatic biology and/or geology.
EEMB 285.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 285.
EEMB 285.description: Participation as a member of the scientific part on Scripps institution  (UCSD), NMFS, and UCSB oceanographic cruises. Cruise duration is variable  (7 to 60 days), and course units will vary with cruise duration.     Supervision by scientific party leader. Report required.

EEMB 288RE.title: Restoration Ecology Seminar
EEMB 288RE.description: Seminar explores current topics in restoration ecology including model   projects, techniques, structured research, performance criteria, political and philosophical issues and may include site visits.

EEMB 290.title: Introduction to Faculty Research
EEMB 290.prereq_description: Strongly encouraged for all first year graduate students; open to
EEMB 290.description: Presentation and discussion of current EEMB faculty research. Informal   discussions follow weekly faculty member research presentations. This  seminar exposes graduate students to the breadth of departmental research, facilitates graduate-faculty interaction, and offers an intellectual   setting for student interaction.

EEMB 292.title: Advanced Special Topics in Biological Sciences
EEMB 292.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
EEMB 292.comments: May be repeated for credit in combination with Biology 292.
EEMB 292.description: Special topics of current importance in biological sciences. Course    content will vary. Information on course content may be obtained in the  department office.

EEMB 500.title: Teaching Assistant Orientation
EEMB 500.comments: Required of all teaching assistants. No unit credit allowed toward   advanceddegree. May be repeated for credit in combination with Biology 500.
EEMB 500.description: General orientation regarding the University of California and the Santa Barbara campus; various pertinent regulations, officials and their   functions, staff and functions; services available to teaching assistants  and to students. Prospective teaching assistants are encouraged to take  this course during the fall quarter prior to their employment.

EEMB 501.title: Practicum in Instruction
EEMB 501.comments: No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree. May be repeated for credit  in combination with Biology 501.
EEMB 501.description: Practical experience in teaching within specified areas of biology.    Students will have responsibility for one or more laboratory and/or    discussion sections. Staff will periodically observe teaching assistants in actual teaching situations. Evaluation forms will be completed by   members of the class sections.

EEMB 502.title: Techniques of Teaching and Laboratory Class Supervision
EEMB 502.comments: Required of all teaching assistants. No unit credit allowed toward   advanceddegree. May be repeated for credit in combination with Biology 502.
EEMB 502.description: Weekly discussion and readings on techniques of teaching including   lecturing, leading discussions, writing and grading exams, student-teacher interactions classroom dynamics, and teaching philosophy.

EEMB 503.title: Research Practium in Biology
EEMB 503.comments: May be repeated for credit in combination with Biology 503.
EEMB 503.description: Basic procedures and methods of research in a specific area as determined  by consultation between the supervising faculty member and the research  assistant. Includes weekly meetings and consultations, and formal    evaluations.

EEMB 507.title: Introduction to Graduate Research
EEMB 507.description: Introduction to research at the graduate level for first-year EEMB graduate students Topics include navigating degree requirements, keeping up to date with the scientific literature, building a professional network, and scientific ethics.

EEMB 508.title: Levels of Biological Organization i: Individuals and Populations
EEMB 508.description: This is the first in a set of two advanced courses in ecology and    evolution, and includes modules on adaptation and organismal function, life history theory and fitness, and population dynamics.

EEMB 509.title: Levels of Biological Organization II: Communities and Ecosystems
EEMB 509.description: This is the second in a set of advanced courses in ecology and     evolution, and includes modules on the origins of diversity, species   interactions and coexistence, the causes and consequences of food-web  complexity, and ecosystem level processes.

EEMB 510.title: Professional Development for Graduate Students
EEMB 510.description: Survey of topics significant to graduate student professional development, including CV preparation, grant proposal writing, and publication. Course  participants have the opportunity to enhance specific academic skills  through interaction with peers and the faculty instructor in a workshop  format.

EEMB 511.title: Writing Science
EEMB 511.description: A hands-on workshop to polish writing skills. Modules focus on story  telling to make ideas compelling, streamlining to make writing compact  and effective, and developing flow of ideas and paragraphs. Students work  on a chapter, paper, or proposal.

EEMB 590.title: EEMB Colloquium
EEMB 590.comments: May be repeated for credit in combination with Biology 590.
EEMB 590.description: Presentation and discussion of recent work in ecology, evolution,    behavioral ecology, evolutionary ecology, physiological ecology, and   marine biology, by eminent and nationally and internationally well known biologists. Optional individual discussion in addition to formal lecture.

EEMB 595A.description: A critical review of research in ecology and evolution.

EEMB 595EV.comments: Individual letter designations may be repeated for credit to a maximum of  36 units.

EEMB 595FA.title: Contentious Topics in Fisheries & Aquaculture
EEMB 595FA.comments: Individual letter designations may be repeated for credit to a maximum of 108 units.
EEMB 595FA.description: A number of topics in fisheries, aquaculture, and marine ecology have become major points of contention in the literature, with growing bodies of evidence that appear to contradict or refute each other without resolution. This seminar introduces the main conflicting topics and key principles of the field. Students weigh the scientific evidence and discuss the broader implications of the unsettled science.

EEMB 595FF.title: Foundations and Frontiers in Ecology
EEMB 595FF.comments: Individual letter designations may be repeated for credit to a maximum of 108 units.
EEMB 595FF.description: Provides an overview of fundamental concepts in ecology and discussion of recent works on these subjects. Topics include population growth and regulation, population structure, metapopulations, metacommunities, coexistence mechanisms, neutral theory, invasibility, predator-prey dynamics, disease, food webs, phenotypic plasticity, metabolic theory, and diversity-ecosystem function relationships.

EEMB 595MM.title: Marine Microbial Ecology
EEMB 595MM.comments: Individual letter designations may be repeated for credit to a maximum of  36 units.
EEMB 595MM.description: A critical review of research in marine microbial ecology.

EEMB 595MR.comments: Individual letter designations may be repeated for credit to a maximum of  36 units.
EEMB 595MR.description: A critical review of research in selected fields of biology.

EEMB 596.comments: May be repeated for credit in combination with Biology 596 up to half of the graduate units required for the M.A. degree.

EEMB 597.title: Individual Study for Master's Comprehensive Examinations and Ph.D.   Examinations
EEMB 597.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
EEMB 597.comments: No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree. Students are limited to 24  units per examination, and 12 units per quarter. May be repeated for   creditin combination with Biology 597.
EEMB 597.description: Individual study for M.A. comprehensive examinations and Ph.D.     examinations.

EEMB 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
EEMB 598.prereq_description: M.A. (thesis) candidate and consent of committee chair.
EEMB 598.comments: May be repeated forcredit in combination with Biology 598 to a maximum of  12 units. No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree.
EEMB 598.description: For research underlying the thesis and writing of the thesis.

EEMB 599.title: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation
EEMB 599.prereq_description: Ph.D. candidate and consent of instructor.
